Retired Scientist Uses Plants In Organic Home Waste Treatment System
DOC.TEXT: The grass isn't greener over Bill Wolverton's septic tank _ he doesn't have one. Nor is his home hooked to a seage treatment system. Wolverton's household sewage flows through 50 feet of pipes, reservoirs and plants along the outside wall of a 1,500-square-foot addition. The plants grown along large windows eat the organic wastes, leaving pure, clean water. ``I wanted to put it in just to show that it can be done and this is what will be done on the moon base, if NASA ever builds a moon base,'' the retired National Aeronautics and Space Administration scientist said. Wolverton's system uses a variation of the ``artificial marsh'' he developed a decade ago. Plants are supported on clay rocks imported from Germany above reservoirs of wastewater. The end roots of the plants reach into the wastewater for nutrients and thrive without fertilizer or watering. The bug problem was corrected by introducing a few chameleons to the indoor system. Wolverton's artificial marsh, in large outdoor versions, is used by several small towns in Mississippi and Louisiana. The system is relatively simple to install and, once operating, presents little or no maintenance costs. ``I think, philosophically, that this sort of system would come closer to meeting the goals of the Clean Water Act than some of the mechanical systems,'' said Barry Royals, of the state Bureau of Pollution Control. ``The problem is that a wetlands system is not the answer to everybody's problem. ``An example of that would be if you tried to build a wetlands system for the city of Jackson. You would take up a good portion of Hinds County and we know that's not practical.'' Interest is growing; Japanese officials visited in October and Wolverton was invited to Holland last month to speak. Things were different 15 years ago, however, when he told the director of Mississippi's Bureau of Pollution Control that sewage could be treated with water hyacinths instead of chemicals. ``He said, `If I stopped to listen to every kook who came in here, I'd never get anything done' and he threw me out of the office.''
